div1.head: Letter fragment to [Henry Rose Carter, Jr.], August 12, 1916
div1.opener:
HOTEL EUROPA, BOGOTÁ
FEDERICO SCHELLER
---------. PROPIETARIO .---------
IMPORTACION DIRECTA DE VINOS Y LICORES
Teléfono No. 825
Apartado No. 358
Telegramas: Europah.
Bogotá, Aug 12 1916
Dear Henry:
div1.p:
Laura sent a letter to your mother
this morning. This will be about a week later I
expect.

We L. Guiteras & myself leave monday mor-
ning - Aug 14 - for Barranquilla. Which we
will reach in about 6 days - possibly 5 1/2 - We
were 9 days coming up - but the current
is with us in the lower Magdalena & that part
of the journey which we made in 6 days
we expect to make in 3. We had an Extra Ex-
press steamer - an acquaintance of Laura's
- a great grandson of old Israel Putnum by then
by - who reached Colon on the same vessel she did
got into Bogota one day ahead of her - having
been 16 days en route from Barranquilla!
How long it took to reach Bogota before steam
boats were put on the Magdalena I don't know
60 to 90 days I should judge of steady traveling.

They

poled up then as the river is so swift that
rowing would be very troublesome. You can
see why it is so little changed from old
Spanish times. It is changed however in
one respect. There are no more mantillas worn
by the women except old ones - of the upper classed, - all black

It is fairly cold here, everyone except myself
& Wrightson is wearing an over coat. The impres-
sion produced on me is the entire absence
of kindliness. The poor & the rich are made of
different clay. A church on every corner
some with jewels worth - a million dollars;
a priests & monks always in evidence;
& much luxury; & beggars every where
Those who can work, work hard & are
thrifty I am told - but practically never
save enough to get ahead. They look
- the workers - miserably poor & dirty, &
- you know how clean the Panameñan was.
Here it is cold & water is scarce & to get it
involves much labor. No one who care
work is begging - but the crippled & the blind
